abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome of the Gueckedou
            Agricultural Development Project for Guinea was
            satisfactory. The project achieved most of its objectives,
            institutional development has been partially achieved,
            sustainability is likely, and the performance of both the
            Bank and Borrower was marginally satisfactory. Several
            lessons can be learned from this project. First, greater
            attention must be paid to the selection and performance of
            technical assistance. Second, the hierarchy of project
            management should include an overseeing body that can review
            project planning and progress from the viewpoint of
            regional, administrative, and national interests. Third,
            careful planning and adequate staffing are necessary before
            the introduction of a credit system. Fourth, Government must
            seek ways to reduce the need for imported inputs and should
            actively encourage research into cropping systems which can
            bring this about. Fifth, there is still a lot to be learned
            about farmers' roles in and attitudes towards the
            production and sale of upland rice seed. Finally, now that
            there is a more cohesive approach and appreciation of the
            value of monitoring and evaluation, it is essential for this
            activity to be well planned and staff trained and provided
            early in the implementation of the project.

abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome of the Gueckedou
            Agricultural Development Project for Guinea was
            satisfactory. The project achieved most of its objectives,
            institutional development has been partially achieved,
            sustainability is likely, and the performance of both the
            Bank and Borrower was marginally satisfactory. Several
            lessons can be learned from this project. First, greater
            attention must be paid to the selection and performance of
            technical assistance. Second, the hierarchy of project
            management should include an overseeing body that can review
            project planning and progress from the viewpoint of
            regional, administrative, and national interests. Third,
            careful planning and adequate staffing are necessary before

10266943.subtopic: Crops and Crop Management Systems,Environmental Economics & Policies,Economic Theory & Research,Agricultural Knowledge and Information Systems,Agricultural Research

0.cdata!:
Guinee - Projet de Developpement
            Agricole de Gueckedou

abstracts.cdata!:
The Gueckedou Agricultural Development
            Project is a continuation of the pilot component of the IDA
            and AfDF financed Rice Development Project (Cr. 952-GUI). It
            aims at increasing the productivity of smallholders in food
            and cash crop production by expanding the scope and area of
            the first phase and introducing technical packages for
            coffee, groundnuts and cassava, and by strengthening the
            Gueckedou Prefectoral Directorate of Rural Development.
            These objectives will be achieved through: (a) providing
            extension services for 16,000 farm families involved in
            cultivation of swamp and upland rice as well as other
            rainfed and perennial crops; (b) providing training for
            Guinean staff and supporting agricultural research to test
            and introduce new technical packages; (c) strengthening the
            management and administration of the prefectoral service;
            (d) seed processing and distribution to farmers; (e)
            development of some 2,000 ha of swamp land through low cost
            irrigation works, and upgrading of 240km of rural roads
            together with their maintenance as well as maintenance of
            260km of existing roads; (f) providing agricultural inputs
            to farmers through credit; and (g) technical assistance,
            consultant services and short and medium term fellowships
            for project staff.
